header.title: Table of Questions for the Meaning of the Words (Part Three)
authors: Author not specified in provided excerpts

central_thesis: This document serves as a comprehensive glossary for advanced Lurianic Kabbalah, providing precise definitions for 101 esoteric terms, thereby explicating the fundamental structures, forces, and processes of divine emanation, the spiritual worlds, and the mechanics of rectification. It aims to clarify the intricate interplay between divine light (Ohr) and vessels (Kelim) as they manifest across various Partzufim and Olamot.

structure_content.summary: This section comprises 101 numbered questions, each presenting a key Kabbalistic term, followed by its detailed definition as understood within the author's specific system. Definitions frequently cross-reference other terms and refer to internal textual citations (e.g., 'Part 3, Chap 8, item 1'), indicating its function as an explanatory aid for a larger, complex work. The terms cover a wide range of concepts from divine lights and vessels to spiritual worlds and processes of interaction.

key_concepts.definition: These are the Kelim of the Sefirot de Guf, meaning the Neʼetzalim from the Masach de Peh de Rosh downwards.
Ohr Hozer, meaning the Ohr Elyon that is not received in Behina Dalet, rejected by her and returns to its place.
The Eser Sefirot de Ohr Yashar that clothe the Masach downward devalue themselves for that purpose.
It is Ohr Hochma.
This is the Eser Sefirot de Ohr Yashar that glitter through the Masach downwards.

When the Atzmut clothes the Kelim, the four Behinot HB TM are designated by four separate Otiot, after the clothing of the Orot in the Aviut of the Kelim, ignoring the Shinui Tzura between them. This Shinui Tzura means separation in spirituality.

The Hizdakchut of the Aviut in Malchut de Malchut in the Guf of every Partzuf, when the Ohr Hozer gradually departs up to the Maatzil, these Eser Sefirot are at that time called “Connected Otiot.” It is to indicate the purification that the Kelim acquire every time, which connects them and brings them closer to the Shoresh. As it's been written in item 6, the Aviut separates while the Zakut connects.

When Ohr Yashar, meaning Ohr Hochma, is not clothed in the Kli, then the Kli is called Achor, or Achoraim. It has been written in item 4 that Ohr Hochma is called Ohr Panim. Thus, in the absence of Ohr Hochma from the Kli, it is called Achor.

It is something that connects and determines between two far ends. From this you can understand the meaning of the names: “Middle Line” and “Middle Pillar” that consist of three Sefirot – Daat, Tifferet, Yesod.

Partzuf Keter is called Arich Anpin because of the Atzmut of Ohr Hochma in it. Tifferet is called Zeir Anpin because it has no more than a minute He'arah of Hochma. The names AA and ZA are parallel, for they relate solely to the Ohr Hochma in the Partzuf, as Hochma is called Ohr Panim.

Malchut is called AT, because she consists of all the Otiot from Aleph to Tav (all the letters of the Hebrew alphabet). It is so because the Otiot are the Kelim of the Sefirot and all the Kelim come from Malchut.

Bohu is another name for Arich Anpin. It is parallel to Tohu, which is another name for Atik. It means negation of attainment, whereas Bohu designates attainment and existence. It is the acronym of Bo Hu (In Him).
The Sefira of Malchut that became separated from the inner Kelim and became a Kli for the Ohr Makif is called Bait or Heichal.

The overcoming of the Ohr on the limiting Masach that stands in its way is called Beki'a. It means that it completely ignores the Gevul that stands in its way, breaks a passage and shines through the Gevul downward.

Innovation of existence from absence is called 'Creation.' The Aviut in the Kelim could not be uncovered in Olam Atzilut, but only from the Karka of Olam Atzilut downwards. Therefore, from that place downward it is called Beria, after the Aviut that appeared. The Aviut is the will to receive in the creature, existence from absence, for everything in reality is regarded as emerging from Him existence from existence. This is because one cannot give what one does not have, except the will to receive, which, by necessity is not in Him, for from whom would He receive?

Eser Sefirot that travel through the Masach downward where the Malchut expands into Eser Sefirot from and within her are called Guf. This is because they are the primary force in the Partzuf, for there is the primary Hitlabshut of the Atzmut in the Kelim.
It is a force of Tzimtzum and Din that was erected in Malchut, rejecting the Ohr Elyon from clothing within her.
Ohr Hozer is called Hevel.

As written by the Rav, the Shoresh of the Orot and their essence is the four simple Otiot of HaVaYaH, without any fillings. However, their fillings are the expansion of HaVaYaH and the exit of their Orot outside. There are five Partzufim: Keter, AB, SAG, MA, BON. Partzuf Keter is the principal among them and their Shoresh. The Eser Sefirot in it are implied in the four simple Otiot HaVaYaH, called inner HaVaYaH.
A 'striking' or 'collision' that occurs in the Masach in Kli de Malchut during a Zivug de Hakaa, leading to the raising of Ohr Hozer.

Hitpashtut Ohr Ein Sof for Zivug de Hakaa in the Masach in Kli de Malchut to raise Ohr Hozer is called Histaklut. It is so because Ohr that expands from Ein Sof is always regarded as Ohr Hochma, called Ohr Eynaim, Sight, or Histaklut.

Wherever there is Hizdakchut of Aviut of a degree, there is also an equal Histalkut of its Ohr and the Shefa. It is so because the measure of the will to receive in the degree is its Aviut. It is therefore obvious that when the will to receive disappears, so does all the Shefa that is taken in her, as there is no coercion in spirituality.
Any Ohr should clothe a Kli, and there is no Ohr without a Kli.
Heʼarah of Ohr Hozer is always called Hitnotzetzut or Nitzotzin.

It is the Ohr Elyon that expands to the Neʼetzal. However, we should understand that it is a Hamshacha from the perspective of the Ratzon in that Ne'etzal, who draws that Hitpashtut of Ohr Elyon to itself according to its measure of yearning. The degree is not completed but in the Hitpashtut of the two Behinot of Hitpashtut of Ohr Ein Sof (see Hitpashtut Bet).
The will to receive in the Neʼetzal is regarded as its general “substance.” Its four Behinot are regarded as the four forms of the Ratzon, called HB TM.

Ohr Hozer that ascends from the Masach in Malchut upwards and clothes the Eser Sefirot de Rosh is called Hotam. The Orot that sparkle from the Masach downwards to Eser Sefirot de Guf are regarded as the imprints of that Hotam.

Hakika and Blita are two parallel discernments in the in the discernment of the Shefa. Blita means that the Shefa is evidently abundant in the Sefirot, and its opposite is the discernment of the Hakika, which implies an evidently great want in the Sefirot.

There is “potential” and there is “actual.” For example, the nucleus of a fruit is considered to be containing the “potential” fruit, but not the 'actual.' Through the sowing and the growth, the fruit comes from the “potential” to the “actual.” In much the same way, we discern the Masach before Ohr Ein Sof expands to it for Zivug de Hakaa, which consists of Eser “potential” Sefirot. Once encountering the Ohr Elyon and raising Eser Sefirot de Ohr Hozer that clothe the Ohr Elyon, it is regarded as the Eser Sefirot de Rosh becoming apparent 'in actuality' as roots for the Kelim.
The Eser Sefirot that glitter and expand from the Masach downward are considered to have complete Kelim; they are called Eser Sefirot de Guf.

The Klipot are of completely opposite Tzura, meaning want only to receive and swallow everything; they haven't any will to bestow whatsoever. For that reason they are separated from the Life of Lives and are therefore called 'Dead' and so is anything that cleaves to them.

It is Eser Sefirot de Ohr Yashar clothed in Ohr Hozer that ascends from the Masach upward, meaning a beginning and a Shoresh. They are not regarded as complete Kelim yet, fit to clothe all the Ohr, but are only regarded as roots.

Eser Sefirot de Ohr Yashar clothed in Eser Sefirot de Ohr Hozer, generated by a Zivug de Hakaa for the first time, are called one Sefira. It is named after the highest Sefira in that level, though it does contain Eser Sefirot in length and Eser Sefirot in depth.

The name Olam begins primarily from Partzuf BON de AK, called Olam ha Nekudim. It is called by that name because ZA and Malchut of the inner Kelim of Behina Dalet disappeared and became Kelim for Ohr Makif, called Levush and Heichal. Olam means He'elem (concealment), though at times the name is borrowed to refer to Sefirot and Partzufim that preceded Olam ha Nekudim, but this is only a borrowed name.
Eser Sefirot one below the other that are generated by the ascent of Malchut to the Maatzil are called Partzufim.

Keter consists of two Behinot, called 'Nitzotz of Creator' and 'Nitzotz of creature.' Behinat 'Nitzotz of Creator' in it is called Atik, and Tohu, named after the complete absence of the attainment in it. The 'Nitzotz of creature' in it is called Arich Anpin and Bohu, indicating the Shoresh and beginning of attainment that is found there.

practical_system.description: While not a 'practical manual' in the grimoire sense, this text delineates the metaphysical system within which all Lurianic Kabbalistic spiritual practice operates. The 'magic' here is the precise understanding and manipulation of divine lights (Orot) and vessels (Kelim) to achieve Tikkun (rectification) and spiritual elevation. The system describes how the 'will to receive' (Aviut) of the vessels interacts with the 'direct light' (Ohr Yashar) through the 'screen' (Masach) to generate 'reflected light' (Ohr Hozer), thereby enabling bestowal. This precise mapping of spiritual dynamics is the 'operative' side: by aligning one's internal spiritual work (Kavanah, prayer, Mitzvot) with these cosmic laws, a practitioner aims to effect change in the higher worlds, facilitate the descent of divine abundance (Shefa), and ultimately bring about the Messianic rectification.

relevant_quotes.text: Innovation of existence from absence is called 'Creation.' The Aviut in the Kelim could not be uncovered in Olam Atzilut, but only from the Karka of Olam Atzilut downwards. Therefore, from that place downward it is called Beria, after the Aviut that appeared. The Aviut is the will to receive in the creature, existence from absence, for everything in reality is regarded as emerging from Him existence from existence. This is because one cannot give what one does not have, except the will to receive, which, by necessity is not in Him, for from whom would He receive?
It is a force of Tzimtzum and Din that was erected in Malchut, rejecting the Ohr Elyon from clothing within her.

The Klipot are of completely opposite Tzura, meaning want only to receive and swallow everything; they haven't any will to bestow whatsoever. For that reason they are separated from the Life of Lives and are therefore called 'Dead' and so is anything that cleaves to them.

Ohr Hozer that ascends from the Masach in Malchut upwards and clothes the Eser Sefirot de Rosh is called Hotam. The Orot that sparkle from the Masach downwards to Eser Sefirot de Guf are regarded as the imprints of that Hotam.

critical_analysis.relevance: This glossary is profoundly relevant for serious students and practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah. It provides the essential technical vocabulary necessary to navigate the intricate and highly systematic cosmology articulated by Isaac Luria and his successors. By meticulously defining terms such as Ohr (Light), Kelim (Vessels), Masach (Screen), Partzufim (Divine Configurations), and the various spiritual worlds (Atzilut, Beria, Yetzira, Assiya), it clarifies the dynamic processes of emanation, contraction (Tzimtzum), and rectification (Tikkun). This precision is vital for understanding the energetic and structural dynamics of the spiritual realms, which forms the metaphysical backdrop for all Kabbalistic spiritual work and the 'magic' of aligning lower reality with higher divine will. It is a foundational text for anyone seeking to decode the symbolic language of Kabbalah and apply its principles accurately.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily advanced students and academic researchers specializing in Lurianic Kabbalah, Jewish mysticism, and Western Esotericism. It assumes a pre-existing foundational understanding of Kabbalistic concepts and is designed to resolve ambiguities and provide the author's specific interpretations of key terms. It would also be valuable for committed practitioners of Qabalah (both Jewish and Hermetic) who aim for a deep, technical understanding of the underlying metaphysical mechanics, rather than merely ritualistic application without theoretical depth.
